message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms of hypothyroidism, indicated by the high TSH level and fatigue, constipation, and weight gain. Levothyroxine is the standard treatment for hypothyroidism. Erythropoietin and packed RBC transfusion are used to treat anemia, which the patient does not have, and prednisone is used for inflammatory conditions, which the patient does not present with.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of hypothyroidism, as confirmed by the elevated TSH. Levothyroxine is the medication of choice for treatment of hypothyroidism. Other options such as erythropoietin, packed RBC transfusion, and prednisone are not relevant to the diagnosis of hypothyroidism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A TSH level of 8.0 µU/mL suggests hypothyroidism, and levothyroxine is the preferred treatment for this condition. Options A, C, and D are not appropriate for the treatment of hypothyroidism.

Levothyroxine is the recommended treatment for hypothyroidism. Erythropoietin and packed RBC transfusion are options for anemia, which the patient does not have. Prednisone is a steroid used to decrease inflammation, but there is no evidence of inflammation in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including fatigue, constipation, weight gain, and elevated TSH levels suggest hypothyroidism. Levothyroxine is the treatment of choice for hypothyroidism. Erythropoietin is used to stimulate red blood cell production, packed RBC transfusion is used for severe anemia, and prednisone is a steroid used to treat inflammation.
